multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the frequency of light waves and the color of an object?

options.label: A
options.text: Low-frequency light waves look blue, high-frequency light waves look red.

options.label: B
options.text: High-frequency light waves look violet, low-frequency light waves look red.

options.label: C
options.text: The frequency of light waves has no effect on the color of an object.

options.label: D
options.text: The color of an object is dependent on the frequency of light waves it absorbs.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when two different frequencies of light waves overlap in the visible spectrum?

options.label: A
options.text: They cancel each other out and create a black color.

options.label: B
options.text: They mix together and create a new frequency of light.

options.label: C
options.text: They co-exist, and our brain perceives a different color due to the combination of signals from the cone cells.

options.label: D
options.text: They are perceived separately as distinct colors.

multiple-choice.question: Where does light perception happen in the human eye?

options.label: A
options.text: In the lens of the eye.

options.label: B
options.text: In the retina, a paper-thin layer of cells that covers the back of the eyeball.

options.label: C
options.text: In the pupil.

options.label: D
options.text: In the cornea.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two types of light-detecting cells in the retina?

options.label: A
options.text: Rods and cones.

options.label: B
options.text: Red and green cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Yellow and blue cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Low-light and high-light cells.

multiple-choice.question: How do the rods and cones in the retina differ in terms of their function?

options.label: A
options.text: Rods are used for seeing in low-light conditions and detecting only brightness, while cones are used for seeing in brighter light conditions and detecting colors.

options.label: B
options.text: Rods are used for seeing in bright light conditions, while cones are used for seeing in low-light conditions.

options.label: C
options.text: Rods are used for detecting colors, while cones are used for detecting brightness.

options.label: D
options.text: Rods and cones are used for detecting both brightness and colors.

multiple-choice.question: How many kinds of cone cells are there in the retina that correspond to different colors?
What happens when yellow light is shining on the eye?

options.label: A
options.text: The red and green cones get activated, and each sends a signal to the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: The yellow cone gets activated, and sends a signal to the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: The blue cone gets activated, and sends a signal to the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Only the red cone gets activated, and sends a signal to the brain.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we detect colors in low-light conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the rods in the retina are not sensitive to color and take over in low-light conditions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the cones in the retina are not sensitive to light.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the cones in the retina are not sensitive to color in low-light conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the rods in the retina are sensitive to color, but not in low-light conditions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the number of physical colors and the human eye's ability to detect them?

options.label: A
options.text: There are infinitely many physical colors, but the brain can be tricked into thinking it's seeing any color by combining three colors.

options.label: B
options.text: There are a few thousand physical colors, and the brain can detect all of them accurately.

options.label: C
options.text: There are a few hundred physical colors, and the brain can detect all of them accurately.

options.label: D
options.text: There are only a few physical colors, and the brain can detect all of them accurately.

multiple-choice.question: What property of human vision allows us to detect a wide range of colors using a limited number of cone cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Color perception

options.label: B
options.text: Color additivity

options.label: C
options.text: Trichromatic vision

options.label: D
options.text: Monochromatic vision

title: You are your microbes - Jessica Green and Karen Guillemin

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the microbial communities in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: They are identical across all individuals with similar lifestyles

options.label: B
options.text: They are composed of a single type of microbe

options.label: C
options.text: No two bodies have the same microbial communities

options.label: D
options.text: They are only found in the gut

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of cellulolytic bacteria in the human gut?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down proteins into amino acids

options.label: B
options.text: To extract energy from sugars through fermentation

options.label: C
options.text: To break down cellulose into simple sugars

options.label: D
options.text: To produce waste products from undigested food

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the simple sugars produced by cellulolytic bacteria in the human gut?

options.label: A
options.text: They are absorbed directly into the bloodstream

options.label: B
options.text: They are converted into proteins for muscle growth

options.label: C
options.text: They are used as fuel by respirators to produce energy

options.label: D
options.text: They are stored as glycogen for later use

multiple-choice.question: Which type of microbe is responsible for extracting energy from sugars in the human gut by converting them into chemicals?

options.label: A
options.text: Respirators

options.label: B
options.text: Syntrophs

options.label: C
options.text: Fermentors

options.label: D
options.text: Cellulolytic bacteria

multiple-choice.question: What are the byproducts of the fermentation process in the human gut?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxygen and water

options.label: B
options.text: Carbon dioxide and methane

options.label: C
options.text: Alcohol and hydrogen gas

options.label: D
options.text: Glucose and amino acids

multiple-choice.question: Which type of microbe ekes out a living off the waste products of fermenters in the human gut?

options.label: A
options.text: Respirators

options.label: B
options.text: Fermentors

options.label: C
options.text: Cellulolytic bacteria

options.label: D
options.text: Syntrophs

multiple-choice.question: What factors contribute to the diversity and membership of our gut microbial community?

options.label: A
options.text: Only our genetic makeup

options.label: B
options.text: Only the microbes we encounter throughout our lives

options.label: C
options.text: Our genetic makeup, the microbes we encounter, and the food we eat

options.label: D
options.text: Only our lifestyle choices

multiple-choice.question: How does a diet of simple molecules affect the gut microbial community?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases diversity and complexity

options.label: B
options.text: It has no impact on the microbial community

options.label: C
options.text: It reduces diversity and puts some microbial workers out of a job

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the microbial community to become extinct

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of gut microbial communities in humans who suffer from diseases like diabetes or chronic gut inflammation?

options.label: A
options.text: High diversity and resilience

options.label: B
options.text: Low diversity and reduced resilience

options.label: C
options.text: Similarity to those in healthy individuals

options.label: D
options.text: Complete extinction of the microbial community

multiple-choice.question: What is likely to help revitalize and promote diversity in our microbial ecosystems in the gut and across the entire body?

options.label: A
options.text: Eating a diet of simple, processed foods

options.label: B
options.text: Taking antibiotics regularly

options.label: C
options.text: Engaging in regular exercise and getting enough sleep, but maintaining a poor diet

options.label: D
options.text: Eating a varied diet of complex, plant-based foods
